thread.title: Did Yankees' Jacoby Ellsbury's benching hurt relationship with Joe Girardi?
thread.title_full: Did Yankees' Jacoby Ellsbury's benching hurt relationship with Joe Girardi?

author: Brendan Kuty | NJ Advance Media for NJ.com
title: Did Yankees' Jacoby Ellsbury's benching hurt relationship with Joe Girardi?
text:
Comments 
NEW YORK — Yankees manager Joe Girardi may have damaged his relationship with center fielder Jacoby Ellsbury by benching him in their American League Wild Card loss Tuesday. 
In his season-ending press conference at Yankee Stadium on Friday , Girardi told reporters he may have to repair things with the $153-million center fielder, who slumped so badly in the second half that he wasn't an option in the Yankees' biggest game of the year, and the biggest one since he joined the team in 2014. 
"As far as fence mending, that's to be determined," the manager said. 
Girardi dropped Ellsbury from the postseason lineup for at least two reasons: the 32-year-old's career numbers against lefties weren't as good as either Chris Young's or Brett Gardner's — the Astros started ace southpaw Dallas Keuchel — and Ellsbury had been just plain awful, hitting .224 in 74 games after returning from a month-long disabled list stint (knee strain), a far cry from the .324 batting average he posted through the season's first 37 games. 
MLB trade rumors: Yankees' most realistic big-league trade pieces 
It didn't work out. 
Young and Gardner combined to go 0-for-6 with four strikeouts as the Yankees lost, 3-0, behind a dominant Keuchel. 
At the time, Girardi said Ellsbury understood the decision. He echoed that sentiment Friday. 
"I thought we had a great conversation that day, and I thought his attitude was great that day," Girardi said. "He had the right attitude. No player wants to sit there. Even the guys who knew they didn't have a chance to start don't want to sit, they want to be out there, but that's the way you want it." 
Ellsbury also said he respected Girardi's decision just before the game. But, while each member of the Yankees was in the clubhouse postgame to speak with reporters and teammates, Ellsbury was nowhere to be found, perhaps unwilling to answer questions about either his standing with the club or his performance. 
Girardi said he speaks with players throughout the offseason and that he may have to talk with Ellsbury, whose contract keeps him in the Bronx the next five years at $21-million a season. 
Girardi said Ellsbury's contract didn't play a role in his benching, adding that Carlos Beltran (three years, $45 million) and Gardner (four years, $52 million) each have "substantial" contracts, too. Gardner's contract was an extension that kicked in this season. Beltran will enter the final year of his deal in 2016. 
"Did it work out? No," Girardi said. "But the question I'm going to get is, if you played Ells would it have been better? Would it have been three runs better? I don't know that. None of us knows that. If I would have played this guy, would it have been better? That sort of thing. Only time will tell."
